article.title: Interlayer Coupling Effect on a Bilayer Kitaev Model

choices: The energy spectrum of the bilayer Kitaev model.
The structure of the bilayer Kitaev model on a honeycomb lattice.
The temperature dependence of the specific heat in the bilayer Kitaev model.
The spatial configuration of local conserved quantities in the bilayer Kitaev model.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the different colors of bonds represent in Figure 1(a) and 1(b)?
choices: Different types of interlayer Heisenberg couplings.
Different types of Kitaev couplings within each layer.
Different eigenvalues of the local conserved quantity.
Different dimer sites within the bi-hexagon.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of the clusters shown in Figure 1(c)?
choices: To study the effect of different boundary conditions on the system.
To perform exact diagonalization calculations for finite-size systems.
To illustrate the formation of dimer singlets in the ground state.
To represent the spatial configurations of triplet excitations.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the shaded hexagon represent in Figure 2?
choices: A plaquette with a local conserved quantity Xp = -1.
A bi-hexagon where a triplet excitation is present.
A dimer site with a singlet ground state.
A bond where the Kitaev interaction is strongest.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the bend structure in Figure 3(b) suggest?
choices: A second-order quantum phase transition in the small 位 region.
A crossover between the Kitaev QSL and singlet-dimer states.
A change in the nature of triplet excitations in the system.
A possible first-order quantum phase transition in the system.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the decrease in the absolute value of Cs with decreasing 位 signify?
choices: Enhancement of the interlayer dimer singlet state.
Suppression of interlayer spin correlations due to the Kitaev coupling.
Increased localization of triplet excitations on the corresponding bonds.
A decrease in the spin gap of the system.

multiple_choice_question.text: What causes the splitting of the excitation energy into two levels in Figure 5?
choices: The presence of both Kitaev and Heisenberg interactions in the system.
The formation of bonding and antibonding states due to triplet excitations.
The finite-size effects present in the exact diagonalization calculations.
The mixing of one-triplon and two-triplon excited states.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the double peak structure in the specific heat at 位 = 0 indicate?
choices: The presence of long-range magnetic order in the Kitaev QSL.
The fractionalization of spin degrees of freedom into itinerant Majorana fermions and localized fluxes.
The formation of dimer singlets due to the interlayer Heisenberg coupling.
The existence of a first-order quantum phase transition in the system.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be inferred from the merging of the double peak structure into a single peak with increasing 位?
choices: The Kitaev QSL becoming more stable at higher temperatures.
The proximity effect of the Kitaev QSL emerging at higher temperatures.
The breakdown of the bond-operator mean-field approximation.
The increase in the spin gap of the system.

multiple_choice_question.text: What conclusion can be drawn about the ground state of the multilayer Kitaev model depicted in Figure 8?
choices: The system exhibits long-range magnetic order with three-dimensional spin correlations.
The ground state is a gapless spin liquid with power-law decay of spin correlations.
The ground state is nonmagnetic and lacks three-dimensional long-range spin correlations.
The system undergoes a first-order quantum phase transition to a dimer singlet state.
